I donâ€™t think you need the `.right` here. `Either` has been right-biased for a while.
Since we're returning the whole history here, would it make more sense to call this endpoint `history` or `log`?
I have thought about that. Don't want to get analysis paralysis on something so trivial. I think status is the right word (even acknowledging that the entire history is returned).
I would recommend to store at least `(LocalDateTime, String)` and render it as a string when you need to.
Yes, @rohanjr advocated for this as well. I'll take care of it.
Please donâ€™t invent your own date/time format. Use RFC 3339 (or ISO 8601 they are basically identical).
Dang SO :) Ok.
It looks like your logs are a memory leak. You only ever write to them but never delete anything. This is probably not a huge issue atm but we should move them to postgres to avoid that.
Yes, there is no attempt to control the memory here at this time. I hadn't considered having this data written to the DB - not against it.
@rohanjr Thoughts?
Makes sense (if the user supplies a db connection)

If you donâ€™t want to go down the route of using sqlite with an in-memory backend so you always have a DB, I think it would be useful to have an abstraction layer somewhere. Inlining this every time we write to the DB is going to become a mess and itâ€™s super easy to have the in-memory mode diverge from the DB-backed mode.
Yes, I'll refactor the in-memory logic into the TriggerDao in a future PR (either next or after `stop` is implemented).
I guess you are leaving this for a separate PR?
Yeah.
I think it's time to have a parameter pack here. The list of parameters just keeps growing. Maybe not in this PR but if it were to be it would be very much in keeping with the rest.

comments.body: Do you have a plan for how to do better than this?

As a matter of a fact I think I do. My idea is that if presented with a token that doesn't match the start token, if the old and new token agree in party, the old token has expired and (in the absence of a better API) we can use the new token to get an ACS (or establish the conditions that starting a trigger would entail), we might conclude we are indeed looking at a valid stop.
This idea has the nice property that it does not require the user presenting a token that has expired. Anyway, what do you think of that?
Is there a timeout on the time between starting and started? If not, should there be one? (not in this PR)
There currently isn't. Not a bad idea.
I donâ€™t think the abbreviation helps here.
I could call this `Token` or `TokenManagement`. In the json-api, I think they use `EndpointsCompaion` for this code. Let's go with `TokenManagement` for now?
You import this here but then you use `TokenMgt.*` most of the time. Can we just kill the import and use the object-qualified version everywhere?
Yes. I mean in a refactoring - I'll get this done today - to move that code out into a dedicated module. I'll sort this at the same time.
Note that the triggers per party will almost certainly not be correct since I can create the actor without having a valid token.
Indeed. Fully agree that only successfully started triggers should get added to any running triggers table. Will work on it.

Sorry I just saw this, but this response format is not quite right. The `"status"` field is supposed to mirror the status code, and there should be a `"result"` field with whatever successful response body you want, i.e. `{"status": 200, "result": value}`. I suggest using the `successResponse` helper function as in the `list` command, where you pass in the JSON `value` you want (could be the string "pass" in this case).

> Sorry I just saw this, but this response format is not quite right. The `"status"` field is supposed to mirror the status code, and there should be a `"result"` field with whatever successful response body you want, i.e. `{"status": 200, "result": value}`. I suggest using the `successResponse` helper function as in the `list` command, where you pass in the JSON `value` you want (could be the string "pass" in this case).

This case intentionally breaks with our internal conventions in order to conform to the referenced RFC (internet standard proposal).
I think you don't need `new` here because it's a case class, but I don't think it matters either.
I found in practice that you do. If you don't put a `new` on it the compiler goes looking for a *value* in `object TriggerRunner` called `Config`.
ah, ok thanks
